content: Ebola virus disease (Ebola, or EVD) is a severe, often fatal disease first detected in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1976. It is spread through contact with infected bodily fluids and has caused a large outbreak in Guinea, Sierra Leone, and Liberia. Nearly 10,000 people have been infected, with almost 5,000 deaths reported. In October, nearly 10,000 people have contracted EVD, with almost 5,000 deaths reported. WHO updates EVD cases regularly at http://www.who.int/ebola. Due to weak surveillance systems, actual cases may be higher than reported. Mali reported its first EVD case, and concerns exist about undetected cases in neighboring countries. WHO is sending a team to Mali for assistance. Efforts are underway to develop drugs for EVD treatment, with plans to test two Ebola vaccines on health workers and volunteers in January. The organization mentioned a potential treatment for Ebola in Liberia by early November. Health practitioners currently provide supportive care for EVD symptoms to reduce fatality rates. Disease spread can be limited through surveillance and containment measures outlined by WHO manuals. Previous Ebola outbreaks were successfully contained using these measures. The current outbreak in West Africa is due to inadequate health systems for implementing containment and surveillance measures. The current Ebola outbreak in West Africa is different from previous outbreaks due to its emergence in new countries and simultaneous multi-country transmission. Efforts to contain the disease have been successful in some countries like Senegal and Nigeria, but new cases are still being investigated in Mali. The outbreak has also resulted in cases outside of Africa for the first time. The current Ebola outbreak in West Africa is unique as it has spread to new countries and is transmitting simultaneously across multiple countries. Efforts to contain the disease have been effective in some countries, but new cases are still under investigation in Mali. In October, health workers in the United States and Spain contracted Ebola while caring for patients, but no additional cases have been reported. The outbreak is spreading in both rural and urban areas, posing challenges for responders in densely populated urban settings with limited access to clean water, sanitation, and healthcare facilities. Ebola is spreading rapidly in affected countries, with cases doubling every 15-40 days in Liberia and Sierra Leone. The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is spreading rapidly, with cases doubling every 30-40 days in Sierra Leone. A separate outbreak in the DRC has resulted in 66 cases and 49 deaths, with congressional actions accelerating to address the situation. In response to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, Congress enacted legislation providing $88 million for CDC Ebola response activities and research for treatments and vaccines. The Department of Defense was also permitted to reprogram $750 million for building Ebola treatment units in Liberia. The affected countries' health systems were already weak before the outbreak. The health systems in the affected countries were weak before the Ebola outbreak and have been overwhelmed by the crisis. WHO identifies six components of a health system: human resources, governance, financing, supply chain, service delivery, and information. The affected countries face severe deficiencies in these areas, enabling the virus to spread. The outbreak has led to perceptions of government ineptitude, with mistrust prompting civilians to resist government responses. Attacks on health workers and facilities have been reported. The affected governments have used armed forces to enforce disease control measures and quarantine neighborhoods, leading to public resentment. Some have criticized the effectiveness of quarantines, citing concerns about human rights, food scarcity, and unrest. Liberia and Sierra Leone have stopped quarantining some neighborhoods following protests and expert criticisms. Despite concerns, Sierra Leone officials considered a sensitization campaign successful, detecting Ebola cases and recovering bodies. Low per capita health spending in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone has contributed to poor conditions in health facilities. Low per capita health spending in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone has led to poor conditions in publicly-funded health facilities. Delays in compensation and benefits for health workers have caused absenteeism and worker shortages, with some workers abandoning their posts during the Ebola outbreak due to safety concerns and unpaid salaries. Financial aid from donors, including the United States, is being provided to support payment of health workers' salaries and other incentives in Liberia. The affected countries lack sufficient financial resources for their Ebola response plans and require ongoing support from donors. The United Nations estimates that Guinea needs $194 million, Liberia needs $473 million, and Sierra Leone needs $220 million to address the health and secondary effects of the Ebola outbreak. Severe shortages of health workers and clinics in Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea are hindering access to medical care and treatment for Ebola patients. Human resource constraints and concerns about health center conditions are leading people to care for the ill on their own, contributing to the spread of the virus. The shortage of medics and health facilities is also affecting people needing care for non-Ebola related issues. Observers are concerned about inadequate access to Ebola care and the impact of clinic closures on maternal and child health in the affected countries. Many health facilities are closed in Liberia due to fear of Ebola, leading to high maternal and child mortality rates. Sierra Leone had a shortage of doctors before the outbreak, and Liberia now has significantly fewer doctors providing clinical care. EVD deaths among health workers have worsened staffing levels. The Ebola outbreak has led to a significant decrease in healthcare workers in Sierra Leone and Liberia, with over 40% of EVD deaths among health workers occurring in Liberia. WHO estimates that at least 250 healthcare workers are needed to treat 70 Ebola patients, and the affected countries require over 13,000 health workers for various tasks. Foreign aid is expected to contribute 5% of the needed personnel, with the rest coming from national health staff. The Ebola outbreak has severely impacted healthcare in affected countries, leading to closures of health facilities and limited access to clinics. This has resulted in people traveling long distances for healthcare, delaying treatment and reducing survival prospects. The lack of healthcare services is hindering efforts to detect and contain the virus. The Ebola outbreak has caused severe shortages in health services, including treatment centers, laboratories, contact tracing, and safe burial services. Most affected countries are struggling to meet the demands, leading to patients being turned away and potentially infecting more people. Liberia is facing the most severe treatment shortage, with only 23% of the needed beds available. The price of disinfectants and medicine has doubled as people try to protect themselves from Ebola.
